posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
Has any team used an air filter on their CoProcessor? Trial N’ Terror is likely going to going to use a UM773Lite on the robot in the upcoming year. And I would like to avoid: https://youtube.com/shorts/HoFoD04pkvI?si=surrFsYZzAzcTL27 (Video credit to: @Woolly ) I know on Trial N’ Terror we try our best to never drill over the robot and avoid as many metal shavings as possible. But we aren’t perfect.

Filters I was thinking of using: McMaster-Carr

Has anyone done something like this before? Please let me know your thoughts. Thank you!

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked: Wouldn’t be a bad idea to dismantle the enclosure and carefully conformal coat the board(s) as well.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Interesting… Hadn’t thought of putting an air filter on a coprocessor. The UM690 had its intake on the bottom, which was against our bellypan (with a small gap) so maybe we lucked out. The rear exhaust was exposed though, but under our indexer.

posts.name: Woolly
posts.cooked: It’s worth a try, though any filter will restrict airflow, you may want to play around with going into the bios and setting the cpu target power lower. We were able to set it as low as 15W without performance completely falling off a cliff.

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked:
We used this filter on all cooling locations, though with a different mini pc. We figured it was a decent tradeoff between allowing cooling and blocking metal shavings. IIRC it raised the temperature of the board by ~10C, so it was actually fairly substantial even though the filter size is not that much.

In addition to the filter, we also conformal coated everything we could. This process took some time and care, but I believe it was worth it. I also expect that this sort of conformal coating helps prevent issues due to shock loading on impacts, which makes it especially important.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: We stuck a pair of 20k RPM server fans on an OrangePi 5 in 2023 and we never shorted anything.
